Do dividend quotes for U.S. stocks include witheld taxes?
pred:
?

Yes, dividend quotes for U.S. stocks do include witheld taxes. The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) requires that dividends be reported on a Form 1099-DIV, which is issued by the brokerage firm or financial institution that paid the dividend. The form shows the amount of dividend paid to each shareholder and the tax withheld.

The tax withheld on dividends is typically 15.3% of the dividend amount, which is calculated as follows:

* 15.3% of the dividend amount = 0.153 x dividend amount
* 15.3% of the dividend amount = $0.153 x dividend amount

The tax withheld is then added to the dividend amount to determine the net dividend amount. For example, if a shareholder receives a $100 dividend, the net dividend amount would be $100 + $15.3 = $115.3.

The net dividend amount is then reported on the shareholder's tax return, which is typically filed with the IRS. The shareholder may be able to claim a deduction for the tax withheld on their dividend income, which can help reduce their taxable income.

It's worth noting that the tax withholding on dividends is typically lower than the tax rate on dividend income, as the tax rate on dividend income is generally lower than the tax rate on ordinary income. Additionally, the tax withholding on dividends is typically applied to the dividend amount, rather than the net dividend amount.

In summary, dividend quotes for U.S. stocks do include witheld
answers: The dividend quoted on a site like the one you linked to on Yahoo shows what 1 investor owning 1 share received from the company. It is not adjusted at all for taxes. (Actually some dividend quotes are adjusted but not for taxes... see below.)  It is not adjusted because most dividends are taxed as ordinary income. This means different rates for different people, and so for simplicity's sake the quotes just show what an investor would be paid.  You're responsible for calculating and paying your own taxes.  From the IRS website: Ordinary Dividends Ordinary (taxable) dividends are the most common type of distribution from a corporation or a mutual fund. They are paid out of earnings and profits and are ordinary income to you. This means they are not capital gains. You can assume that any dividend you receive on common or preferred stock is an ordinary dividend unless the paying corporation or mutual fund tells you otherwise. Ordinary dividends will be shown in box 1a of the Form 1099-DIV you receive. Now my disclaimer... what you see on a normal stock quote for dividend in Yahoo or Google Finance is adjusted. (Like here for GE.) Many corporations actually pay out quarterly dividends. So the number shown for a dividend will be the most recent quarterly dividend [times] 4 quarters. To find out what you would receive as an actual payment, you would need to divide GE's current $0.76 dividend by 4 quarters... $0.19. So you would receive that amount for each share of stock you owned in GE.

answers: A stop-loss order becomes a market order when a trade has occurred at or below the trigger price you set when creating the order. This means that you could possibly end up selling some or all of your position at a price lower than your trigger price. For relatively illiquid securities your order may be split into transactions with several buyers at different prices and you could see a significant drop in price between the first part of the order and the last few shares. To mitigate this, brokers also offer a stop-limit order, where you set not only a trigger price, but also a minimum price that you are will to accept for your shares. This reduces the risk of selling at rock bottom prices, especially if you are selling a very large position. However, in the case of a flash crash where other sellers are driving the price below your limit, that part of your order may never execute and you could end up being stuck with a whole lot of shares that are worth less than both your stop loss trigger and limit price. For securities that are liquid and not very volatile, either option is a pretty safe way to cut your losses. For securities that are illiquid and/or very volatile a stop-limit order will prevent you from cashing out at bottom dollar and giving away a bargain to lurkers hanging out at the bottom of the market, but you may end up stuck with shares you don't want for longer than originally planned. It's up to you to decide which kind of risk you prefer.

Can another tax loss be used to offset capital gains taxes? How does it work?
pred:
Yes, another tax loss can be used to offset capital gains taxes. This is known as a "carry forward" or "carry forward loss" strategy. Here's how it works:

1. You have a capital gain from a sale of an investment, such as a stock or real estate.
2. You have a tax loss from a previous year that offsets the capital gain.
3. You can carry forward the tax loss from the previous year to offset future capital gains.

For example, let's say you sold a stock for a loss of $10,000 and had a capital gain of $20,000. You can carry forward the $10,000 tax loss to offset the $20,000 capital gain in the next year. This way, you can reduce your tax liability on the $20,000 capital gain.

The key is to keep track of your losses and gains throughout the year. You can use a tax-loss harvesting strategy to identify and sell investments that have a loss, and then carry forward the losses to offset future gains.

It's also worth noting that you can carry forward losses from one year to another, but you can only carry forward up to a certain amount each year. For example, you can carry forward up to $3,000 in losses from one year to offset capital gains in the next year.

Overall, a carry forward loss strategy can be a powerful tool for reducing your tax liability and optimizing your investment portfolio. It's essential to keep accurate records

A sale of any asset held for over a year to your day, and sold at a loss, will create a loss that is long-term. When capital gains and losses are reported from the tax return, the taxpayer must first categorize all gains and losses between long and short term, and then aggregate the sum total amounts for every single regarding the four categories. Then the gains that are long-term losses are netted against each other, therefore the same is done for short-term gains and losses. Then your net gain that is long-term loss is netted against the net short-term gain or loss. This final net number is then reported on Form 1040. Example Frank has the following gains and losses from his stock trading for the year: Short-term gains - $6,000 Long-term gains - $4,000 Short-term losses - $2,000 Long-term losses - $5,000 Net short-term gain/loss - $4,000 ST gain ($6,000 ST gain - $2,000 ST loss) Net long-term gain/loss - $1,000 LT loss ($4,000 LT gain - $5,000 LT loss) Final net gain/loss - $3,000 short-term gain ($4,000 ST gain - $1,000 LT loss)   Again, Frank can only deduct $3,000 of final net short- or long-term losses against other types of income for that year and must carry forward any remaining balance.

What happens to the money?

High frequency trading (HFT) is a type of trading that involves buying and selling securities at extremely high speeds, often in fractions of a second. It's a high-risk, high-reward strategy that requires a deep understanding of financial markets and instruments.

When HFT firms buy securities, they typically use a combination of algorithms and sophisticated computer systems to analyze market data and execute trades. These trades are usually executed in a matter of milliseconds, allowing HFT firms to profit from small price movements in the market.

However, HFT firms often face liquidity issues, particularly if they don't have sufficient capital to cover their trades. In such cases, they may need to sell securities at a loss to raise capital. This can happen if the market price of the security falls below the firm's cost price, or if the firm's position becomes too large and it needs to close out its position to avoid significant losses.

If HFT firms are unable to sell securities at a profit, they may need to hold onto them for an extended period, which can lead to a loss of capital. In extreme cases, they may even need to sell securities at a loss to raise capital, which can result in significant losses for the firm.

To mitigate these risks, HFT firms often use various strategies, such as hedging, stop-loss orders, and position sizing. They also work closely with their brokers and other market participants to ensure that they have access to sufficient capital to execute trades.

Is a debt collector allowed to make a hard inquiry on your credit report?
pred:
A debt collector can make a hard inquiry on your credit report, but there are limits and requirements.

In the United States, the Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA) regulates the use of credit reports. A hard inquiry is a request to obtain a credit report from a credit reporting agency. A debt collector can make a hard inquiry on your credit report if they have a valid reason for doing so, such as to verify the debt.

However, there are limits on the number of hard inquiries you can make in a 30-day period. The FCRA requires that a debt collector not make more than one hard inquiry in a 30-day period. If a debt collector makes more than one hard inquiry, it may be considered a "pattern of abusive behavior."

Additionally, the FCRA requires that a debt collector provide you with a copy of your credit report and a summary of the inquiries they have made on your credit report. This is known as the "right to know" provision.

It's also worth noting that the FCRA prohibits debt collectors from using your credit report to make a hard inquiry without your consent. If a debt collector makes a hard inquiry without your consent, it may be considered a "deceptive practice."

To protect yourself, it's a good idea to:

* Keep a record of all hard inquiries you receive
* Request a copy of your credit report and a summary of the inquiries
* Check your credit report regularly to ensure it is accurate
* Consider disputing any errors
answers: According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act: any consumer reporting agency may furnish a consumer report [...] to a person which it has reason to believe [...] intends to use the information in connection with a credit transaction involving the consumer on whom the information is to be furnished and   involving the extension of credit to, or review or collection of an account of, the consumer See p12 (section 604). The usual interpretation of this that I've heard is that a debt collection agency that owns or has been assigned a debt can make hard pulls on your credit report without your consent. This link seems to support that (and references the same part of the act, among others): According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act, [...], any business can access your credit history without your permission provided the business has a valid "permissible purpose." The FCRA notes that one such permissible purpose is to review your credit information in connection with the collection of a debt. Thus, if you owe money to a debt collector, the debt collector has the legal right to pull and review your credit report. If they haven't been assigned the debt or own it outright, I believe you have a legal right to dispute it. Consult a lawyer if this is actually a situation you face.  Once use for this is if the debt collection agency has trouble locating you; since your credit report normally contains current and past addresses, this is one way to locate you.

Yes, dividend quotes for U.S. stocks do include witheld taxes. The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) requires that dividends be reported on a Form 1099-DIV, which is issued by the brokerage firm or financial institution that paid the dividend. The form shows the amount of dividend paid to each shareholder and the tax withheld.

The tax withheld on dividends is typically 15.3% of the dividend amount, which is calculated as follows:

* 15.3% of the dividend amount = 0.153 x dividend amount
* 15.3% of the dividend amount = $0.153 x dividend amount

The tax withheld is then added to the dividend amount to determine the net dividend amount. For example, if a shareholder receives a $100 dividend, the net dividend amount would be $100 + $15.3 = $115.3.

The net dividend amount is then reported on the shareholder's tax return, which is typically filed with the IRS. The shareholder may be able to claim a deduction for the tax withheld on their dividend income, which can help reduce their taxable income.

It's worth noting that the tax withholding on dividends is typically lower than the tax rate on dividend income, as the tax rate on dividend income is generally lower than the tax rate on ordinary income. Additionally, the tax withholding on dividends is typically applied to the dividend amount, rather than the net dividend amount.

In summary, dividend quotes for U.S. stocks do include witheld

From the IRS website: Ordinary Dividends Ordinary (taxable) dividends are the most common type of distribution from a corporation or a mutual fund. You can assume that any dividend you receive on common or preferred stock is an ordinary dividend unless the paying corporation or mutual fund tells you otherwise. (Like here for GE.) Many corporations actually pay out quarterly dividends. So the number shown for a dividend will be the most recent quarterly dividend [times] 4 quarters. To find out what you would receive as an actual payment, you would need to divide GE's current $0.76 dividend by 4 quarters... $0.19. So you would receive that amount for each share of stock you owned in GE.

4. **Lack of consideration of market conditions**: Stop-loss is not a substitute for proper market analysis and risk management. It's essential to consider market conditions, such as volatility and liquidity, when setting stop-loss levels.
5. **Potential for unintended consequences**: Stop-loss can lead to unintended consequences, such as selling a security at a loss when it's still in the money, or holding onto a security for too long when it's no longer profitable.

* Set stop-loss levels based
answers: A stop-loss order becomes a market order when a trade has occurred at or below the trigger price you set when creating the order. This means that you could possibly end up selling some or all of your position at a price lower than your trigger price. For relatively illiquid securities your order may be split into transactions with several buyers at different prices and you could see a significant drop in price between the first part of the order and the last few shares. To mitigate this, brokers also offer a stop-limit order, where you set not only a trigger price, but also a minimum price that you are will to accept for your shares. This reduces the risk of selling at rock bottom prices, especially if you are selling a very large position. However, in the case of a flash crash where other sellers are driving the price below your limit, that part of your order may never execute and you could end up being stuck with a whole lot of shares that are worth less than both your stop loss trigger and limit price. For securities that are liquid and not very volatile, either option is a pretty safe way to cut your losses. For securities that are illiquid and/or very volatile a stop-limit order will prevent you from cashing out at bottom dollar and giving away a bargain to lurkers hanging out at the bottom of the market, but you may end up stuck with shares you don't want for longer than originally planned. It's up to you to decide which kind of risk you prefer.

Can another tax loss be used to offset capital gains taxes? How does it work?
pred:
Yes, another tax loss can be used to offset capital gains taxes. This is known as a "carry forward" or "carry forward loss" strategy. Here's how it works:

1. You have a capital gain from a sale of an investment, such as a stock or real estate.
2. You have a tax loss from a previous year that offsets the capital gain.
3. You can carry forward the tax loss from the previous year to offset future capital gains.

For example, let's say you sold a stock for a loss of $10,000 and had a capital gain of $20,000. You can carry forward the $10,000 tax loss to offset the $20,000 capital gain in the next year. This way, you can reduce your tax liability on the $20,000 capital gain.

The key is to keep track of your losses and gains throughout the year. You can use a tax-loss harvesting strategy to identify and sell investments that have a loss, and then carry forward the losses to offset future gains.

It's also worth noting that you can carry forward losses from one year to another, but you can only carry forward up to a certain amount each year. For example, you can carry forward up to $3,000 in losses from one year to offset capital gains in the next year.

Overall, a carry forward loss strategy can be a powerful tool for reducing your tax liability and optimizing your investment portfolio. It's essential to keep accurate records
answers: Capital losses do mirror capital gains within their holding periods. An asset or investment this is certainly held for a year into the day or less, and sold at a loss, will create a short-term capital loss. A sale of any asset held for over a year to your day, and sold at a loss, will create a loss that is long-term. When capital gains and losses are reported from the tax return, the taxpayer must first categorize all gains and losses between long and short term, and then aggregate the sum total amounts for every single regarding the four categories. Then the gains that are long-term losses are netted against each other, therefore the same is done for short-term gains and losses. Then your net gain that is long-term loss is netted against the net short-term gain or loss. This final net number is then reported on Form 1040. Example Frank has the following gains and losses from his stock trading for the year: Short-term gains - $6,000 Long-term gains - $4,000 Short-term losses - $2,000 Long-term losses - $5,000 Net short-term gain/loss - $4,000 ST gain ($6,000 ST gain - $2,000 ST loss) Net long-term gain/loss - $1,000 LT loss ($4,000 LT gain - $5,000 LT loss) Final net gain/loss - $3,000 short-term gain ($4,000 ST gain - $1,000 LT loss)   Again, Frank can only deduct $3,000 of final net short- or long-term losses against other types of income for that year and must carry forward any remaining balance.

How does high frequency trading work if money isn't available for 2-3 days after selling?
pred:
What happens to the money?

High frequency trading (HFT) is a type of trading that involves buying and selling securities at extremely high speeds, often in fractions of a second. It's a high-risk, high-reward strategy that requires a deep understanding of financial markets and instruments.

When HFT firms buy securities, they typically use a combination of algorithms and sophisticated computer systems to analyze market data and execute trades. These trades are usually executed in a matter of milliseconds, allowing HFT firms to profit from small price movements in the market.

However, HFT firms often face liquidity issues, particularly if they don't have sufficient capital to cover their trades. In such cases, they may need to sell securities at a loss to raise capital. This can happen if the market price of the security falls below the firm's cost price, or if the firm's position becomes too large and it needs to close out its position to avoid significant losses.

If HFT firms are unable to sell securities at a profit, they may need to hold onto them for an extended period, which can lead to a loss of capital. In extreme cases, they may even need to sell securities at a loss to raise capital, which can result in significant losses for the firm.

To mitigate these risks, HFT firms often use various strategies, such as hedging, stop-loss orders, and position sizing. They also work closely with their brokers and other market participants to ensure that they have access to sufficient capital to execute trades.

prompt:
You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

My medical bill went to a collection agency. Can I pay it directly to the hospital?
pred:
Generally, it's not recommended to pay a medical bill directly to the hospital. Here's why:

1. **Collection agency fees**: The hospital may charge a collection agency a fee for collecting the debt, which can range from 25% to 50% of the original amount.
2. **Lack of control**: By paying directly to the hospital, you may not have control over the amount you pay or the payment method.
3. **Potential for further collection**: The hospital may still try to collect the debt from you, even if you pay directly to the collection agency.

Instead, consider the following options:

1. **Contact the collection agency**: Reach out to the collection agency and explain your situation. They may be willing to work with you to set up a payment plan or reduce the amount owed.
2. **Negotiate with the hospital**: Contact the hospital directly and ask if they can waive the collection agency fee or offer a payment plan.
3. **Seek assistance from a patient advocate**: If you're struggling to pay your bill, consider reaching out to a patient advocate or a patient assistance program (PAP) offered by the hospital.
4. **Look into financial assistance programs**: Some hospitals offer financial assistance programs or scholarships for patients who are struggling to pay their bills.

Remember, it's essential to communicate with the hospital and the collection agency to find a solution that works for you. Be patient, and don't hesitate to seek help if you're struggling to pay

prompt:
You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Is a debt collector allowed to make a hard inquiry on your credit report?
pred:
A debt collector can make a hard inquiry on your credit report, but there are limits and requirements.

In the United States, the Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA) regulates the use of credit reports. A hard inquiry is a request to obtain a credit report from a credit reporting agency. A debt collector can make a hard inquiry on your credit report if they have a valid reason for doing so, such as to verify the debt.

However, there are limits on the number of hard inquiries you can make in a 30-day period. The FCRA requires that a debt collector not make more than one hard inquiry in a 30-day period. If a debt collector makes more than one hard inquiry, it may be considered a "pattern of abusive behavior."

Additionally, the FCRA requires that a debt collector provide you with a copy of your credit report and a summary of the inquiries they have made on your credit report. This is known as the "right to know" provision.

It's also worth noting that the FCRA prohibits debt collectors from using your credit report to make a hard inquiry without your consent. If a debt collector makes a hard inquiry without your consent, it may be considered a "deceptive practice."

To protect yourself, it's a good idea to:

* Keep a record of all hard inquiries you receive
* Request a copy of your credit report and a summary of the inquiries
* Check your credit report regularly to ensure it is accurate
* Consider disputing any errors
answers: According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act: any consumer reporting agency may furnish a consumer report [...] to a person which it has reason to believe [...] intends to use the information in connection with a credit transaction involving the consumer on whom the information is to be furnished and   involving the extension of credit to, or review or collection of an account of, the consumer See p12 (section 604). The usual interpretation of this that I've heard is that a debt collection agency that owns or has been assigned a debt can make hard pulls on your credit report without your consent. This link seems to support that (and references the same part of the act, among others): According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act, [...], any business can access your credit history without your permission provided the business has a valid "permissible purpose." The FCRA notes that one such permissible purpose is to review your credit information in connection with the collection of a debt. Thus, if you owe money to a debt collector, the debt collector has the legal right to pull and review your credit report. If they haven't been assigned the debt or own it outright, I believe you have a legal right to dispute it. Consult a lawyer if this is actually a situation you face.  Once use for this is if the debt collection agency has trouble locating you; since your credit report normally contains current and past addresses, this is one way to locate you.
